properties.name: Mountain pine beetle epidemic killing forests, Colorado, USA
properties.Bullet 1: From 2009 to 2010, mountain pine beetle activity increased more than 10-fold infesting 200,000 acres (80,000 hectares) on the Front Range—mountains at the foot of the Rockies close to towns and cities.7
properties.Bullet 2: Rocky Mountain National Park—one of the10 most visited parks in the United States—has suffered extensive damage from the mountain pine beetle.8,7
properties.Bullet 3: By killing off millions of acres (hectares) of trees in North America, the mountain pine beetle has turned infested lodgepole and ponderosa pine forests into a source of atmospheric carbon as the trees die, decay, and at times become a tinderbox for wildfires.9
properties.Hot Spot Image Caption: Dead red trees cover the mountainsides in Rocky Mountain National Park. This is just one location in the Rockies where mountain pine beetles have killed millions of trees. The destructive beetles have multiplied quickly throughout the mountain range, largely because of warmer temperatures.1
properties.Intro: The mountain pine beetle's ability to survive and multiply rapidly is highly sensitive to temperature2,3 and precipitation.4 Warmer average temperatures allow pine beetles to complete their life cycle in just one year instead of two.3,5 Rising minimum temperatures in the Colorado Rockies have allowed more beetles to survive the winter.2,6
properties.description: .uppercase { text-transform:uppercase; } sup, sub { vertical-align: 0; position: relative; } sup { bottom: 0.8ex; } sub { top: 0.8ex; } table {font-family:Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; } Rocky Mountains, Colorado, USA Other Impacts Temperature (Air) People (Costs) Dead red trees cover the mountainsides in Rocky Mountain National Park. This is just one location in the Rockies where mountain pine beetles have killed millions of trees. The destructive beetles have multiplied quickly throughout the mountain range, largely because of warmer temperatures.1 Key Facts The mountain pine beetle's ability to survive and multiply rapidly is highly sensitive to temperature2,3 and precipitation.4 Warmer average temperatures allow pine beetles to complete their life cycle in just one year instead of two.3,5 Rising minimum temperatures in the Colorado Rockies have allowed more beetles to survive the winter.2,6 From 2009 to 2010, mountain pine beetle activity increased more than 10-fold infesting 200,000 acres (80,000 hectares) on the Front Range—mountains at the foot of the Rockies close to towns and cities.7 Rocky Mountain National Park—one of the10 most visited parks in the United States—has suffered extensive damage from the mountain pine beetle.8,7 By killing off millions of acres (hectares) of trees in North America, the mountain pine beetle has turned infested lodgepole and ponderosa pine forests into a source of atmospheric carbon as the trees die, decay, and at times become a tinderbox for wildfires.9 climatehotmap.org Climate Hot Map is a project of the Union of Concerned Scientists. See detail page for endnotes.
properties.Map Marker Label: Mountain pine beetle epidemic killing forests, Colorado, USA
properties.Hot Spot Image Alt Text: Trees destroyed by pine beetle in Rocky Mountains, Colorado, USA.

properties.name: Warmer weather leads to beetle epidemic in British Columbia, Canada
properties.Bullet 1: Temperatures in the interior mountain ranges of British Columbia have risen faster than the global average, particularly during the winter.5,6
properties.Bullet 2: By 2010 the mountain pine beetle had killed almost 24.5 billion cubic feet (692 million cubic meters) of timber since scientists began tracking the infestation in 1999.  That is more than nine times the allowable annual timber cut in British Columbia.8
properties.Bullet 3: The beetles have now managed to cross the Continental Divide, threatening the jack pine forests that reach across the continent to the East Coast of Canada and the United States.9,10
properties.Bullet 4: By killing off millions of acres of trees, the mountain pine beetle has turned infested lodgepole pine forests into a source of atmospheric carbon as the trees decay.11
properties.Hot Spot Image Caption: Dead trees stretch as far as the eye can see in Prince George, British Columbia. Because of slightly warmer temperatures, the mountain pine beetle has survived harsh winters in the mountains of the province, attacking more than 43 million acres (17.5 million hectares) of forest and killing millions of trees. That area is larger than all of New England.1
properties.Intro: The mountain pine beetle's ability to survive and multiply rapidly is highly sensitive to temperature2,3 and precipitation.4
properties.description: .uppercase { text-transform:uppercase; } sup, sub { vertical-align: 0; position: relative; } sup { bottom: 0.8ex; } sub { top: 0.8ex; } table {font-family:Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; } British Columbia, Canada Other Impacts Temperature (Air) People (Costs) Dead trees stretch as far as the eye can see in Prince George, British Columbia. Because of slightly warmer temperatures, the mountain pine beetle has survived harsh winters in the mountains of the province, attacking more than 43 million acres (17.5 million hectares) of forest and killing millions of trees. That area is larger than all of New England.1 Key Facts The mountain pine beetle's ability to survive and multiply rapidly is highly sensitive to temperature2,3 and precipitation.4 Temperatures in the interior mountain ranges of British Columbia have risen faster than the global average, particularly during the winter.5,6 By 2010 the mountain pine beetle had killed almost 24.5 billion cubic feet (692 million cubic meters) of timber since scientists began tracking the infestation in 1999. That is more than nine times the allowable annual timber cut in British Columbia.8 The beetles have now managed to cross the Continental Divide, threatening the jack pine forests that reach across the continent to the East Coast of Canada and the United States.9,10 By killing off millions of acres of trees, the mountain pine beetle has turned infested lodgepole pine forests into a source of atmospheric carbon as the trees decay.11 climatehotmap.org Climate Hot Map is a project of the Union of Concerned Scientists. See detail page for endnotes.
properties.Map Marker Label: Warmer weather leads to beetle epidemic in British Columbia, Canada
properties.Hot Spot Image Alt Text: Dead trees stretch as far as the eye can see in Prince George, British Columbia.

properties.name: Globally unique plant species threatened in South Africa
properties.Bullet 1: Many of the region's 2,285 recorded plant species are endemic: they live only here.5
properties.Bullet 2: Proteas are the most common, best-recognized species of fynbos -- vegetation unique to the region. Scientists project that global warming could cause 21-40 percent of proteas to disappear.2,23
properties.Bullet 3: Unless we make deep and swift cuts in our heat-trapping emissions, the fynbos plant community could lose about two-thirds of its area.22,23
properties.Hot Spot Image Caption: The distinctive land ecosystem of South Africa's Cape Floral Region boasts one of the world's highest densities of plant species -- including various flowering proteas, such as the one shown here. Unless we act now to rein in climate change, warming and drying of the region's Mediterranean climate could wipe out proteas and other varieties of shrubby vegetation known as fynbos, which are found only in this region.1
properties.Intro: South Africa's Cape Floral Region is a small area densely packed with an exceptionally high number of plant species.2 This United Nations World Heritage Site7 and biodiversity hotspot8 is at grave risk from climate change.
properties.description: .uppercase { text-transform:uppercase; } sup, sub { vertical-align: 0; position: relative; } sup { bottom: 0.8ex; } sub { top: 0.8ex; } table {font-family:Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; } Cape Floral Region, South Africa Other Impacts Temperature (Air) Freshwater (Extreme dry) The distinctive land ecosystem of South Africa's Cape Floral Region boasts one of the world's highest densities of plant species -- including various flowering proteas, such as the one shown here. Unless we act now to rein in climate change, warming and drying of the region's Mediterranean climate could wipe out proteas and other varieties of shrubby vegetation known as fynbos, which are found only in this region.1 Key Facts South Africa's Cape Floral Region is a small area densely packed with an exceptionally high number of plant species.2 This United Nations World Heritage Site7 and biodiversity hotspot8 is at grave risk from climate change. Many of the region's 2,285 recorded plant species are endemic: they live only here.5 Proteas are the most common, best-recognized species of fynbos -- vegetation unique to the region. Scientists project that global warming could cause 21-40 percent of proteas to disappear.2,23 Unless we make deep and swift cuts in our heat-trapping emissions, the fynbos plant community could lose about two-thirds of its area.22,23 climatehotmap.org Climate Hot Map is a project of the Union of Concerned Scientists. See detail page for endnotes.
properties.Map Marker Label: Globally unique plant species threatened in South Africa
properties.Hot Spot Image Alt Text: Coral- hued proteas bloom in South Africa's Cape Floral Region.

properties.Hot Spot Name: Salonga National Park, Democratic Republic of Congo
properties.name: Unique habitat of endangered species threatened in the Congo
properties.Bullet 1: Salonga provides the sole habitat for many endangered species, including the dwarf chimpanzee (bonobo), the Congo peacock, the forest elephant, and the African slender-snouted or "false" crocodile.2
properties.Bullet 2: The warming trend in Africa has accelerated since the 1960s.6 The Congo Basin became warmer and drier in the latter part of the twentieth century.7
properties.Bullet 3: If we do nothing to reduce our heat-trapping emissions,9 Salonga faces a net loss of around seven species of mammals by 2050, and 19 species by 2080.10
properties.Hot Spot Image Caption: Climate change is one of multiple stressors that threaten the rich, biologically diverse land ecosystem of the Congo Basin. The Congo River winds through Salonga National Park, recognized by the United Nations for providing the world's only habitat for many endangered species.1
properties.Intro: The Democratic Republic of the Congo's remote Salonga National Park -- accessible only by water -- is Africa's largest tropical rainforest reserve.2 Global warming is adding to pressures such as war, deforestation, and poaching, with potentially devastating consequences for the country and its stunning biodiversity.5,4,3
properties.description: .uppercase { text-transform:uppercase; } sup, sub { vertical-align: 0; position: relative; } sup { bottom: 0.8ex; } sub { top: 0.8ex; } table {font-family:Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; } Salonga National Park, Democratic Republic of Congo Other Impacts Temperature (Air) People (Costs) Climate change is one of multiple stressors that threaten the rich, biologically diverse land ecosystem of the Congo Basin. The Congo River winds through Salonga National Park, recognized by the United Nations for providing the world's only habitat for many endangered species.1 Key Facts The Democratic Republic of the Congo's remote Salonga National Park -- accessible only by water -- is Africa's largest tropical rainforest reserve.2 Global warming is adding to pressures such as war, deforestation, and poaching, with potentially devastating consequences for the country and its stunning biodiversity.5,4,3 Salonga provides the sole habitat for many endangered species, including the dwarf chimpanzee (bonobo), the Congo peacock, the forest elephant, and the African slender-snouted or "false" crocodile.2 The warming trend in Africa has accelerated since the 1960s.6 The Congo Basin became warmer and drier in the latter part of the twentieth century.7 If we do nothing to reduce our heat-trapping emissions,9 Salonga faces a net loss of around seven species of mammals by 2050, and 19 species by 2080.10 climatehotmap.org Climate Hot Map is a project of the Union of Concerned Scientists. See detail page for endnotes.
properties.Map Marker Label: Unique habitat of endangered species threatened in the Congo
properties.Hot Spot Image Alt Text: Man floats on river raft through Salonga National Park.

properties.name: Namibian endangered black rhinoceroses at risk
properties.Bullet 1: Game spotting draws the majority of tourists to Namibia,7 and national parks generate N$1 billion to $2 billion (U.S. $130 to $265 million) in income annually.8
properties.Bullet 2: Temperatures in Namibia have been rising at three times the global average rate for the twentieth century, and scientists expect the climate to continue to become hotter and drier -- which could reduce the range and number of wildlife supported by Etosha.9
properties.Bullet 3: If we do nothing to reduce our heat-trapping emissions,12 Etosha faces a net loss of around eight species of mammals by 2050.13
properties.Hot Spot Image Caption: The ecosystem of Namibia's Etosha National Park harbors one of the largest populations of the critically endangered black rhinoceros. Rhinos are protected from poaching in Etosha, but global warming is adding to stress on biodiversity in Africa, and could put game-spotting tourism in Namibia at risk.1
properties.Intro: Etosha National Park in northern Namibia, one of Africa's major wildlife sanctuaries,2 is home to the critically endangered black rhinoceros.5,6 Climate change threatens biodiversity in the park and elsewhere in Africa,11 and a warmer, drier climate in Namibia could put tourism at risk.10
properties.description: .uppercase { text-transform:uppercase; } sup, sub { vertical-align: 0; position: relative; } sup { bottom: 0.8ex; } sub { top: 0.8ex; } table {font-family:Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; } Etosha National Park, Namibia Other Impacts Temperature (Air) People (Costs) The ecosystem of Namibia's Etosha National Park harbors one of the largest populations of the critically endangered black rhinoceros. Rhinos are protected from poaching in Etosha, but global warming is adding to stress on biodiversity in Africa, and could put game-spotting tourism in Namibia at risk.1 Key Facts Etosha National Park in northern Namibia, one of Africa's major wildlife sanctuaries,2 is home to the critically endangered black rhinoceros.5,6 Climate change threatens biodiversity in the park and elsewhere in Africa,11 and a warmer, drier climate in Namibia could put tourism at risk.10 Game spotting draws the majority of tourists to Namibia,7 and national parks generate N$1 billion to $2 billion (U.S. $130 to $265 million) in income annually.8 Temperatures in Namibia have been rising at three times the global average rate for the twentieth century, and scientists expect the climate to continue to become hotter and drier -- which could reduce the range and number of wildlife supported by Etosha.9 If we do nothing to reduce our heat-trapping emissions,12 Etosha faces a net loss of around eight species of mammals by 2050.13 climatehotmap.org Climate Hot Map is a project of the Union of Concerned Scientists. See detail page for endnotes.
properties.Map Marker Label: Namibian endangered black rhinoceroses at risk
properties.Hot Spot Image Alt Text: This black rhinoceros in Etosha National Park, Namibia, is one of several species endangered by hotter and drier conditions.

properties.name: Migrating birds arriving earlier in Germany
properties.Bullet 1: Nearly two-fifths of the first spring arrival dates of birds in Europe and North America in the second half the twentieth century occurred significantly earlier than historically, while only 2 percent occurred significantly later.9
properties.Bullet 2: Scientists found that warmer temperatures correlated with earlier arrival of small migratory songbirds at Heligoland, Germany, and other sites across northern Europe.10
properties.Bullet 3: The effects of global warming in Germany are not limited to birds. Ten spring phases of flowering and leaf unfolding occurred on average 1.6 days earlier each decade in the second half of the twentieth century.16
properties.Hot Spot Image Caption: Because global warming is changing Europe's ecosystems, migrating songbirds -- and springtime -- are arriving earlier in Heligoland, Germany. This major North Sea flyway is the site of a bird observatory where scientists developed a funnel-shaped trap now used to study migrating birds around the world.1
properties.Intro: From the flowering of plants to the arrival of migrating birds, spring is coming earlier to Germany.10,16 Shifts in the seasons show that Europe's climate is changing -- with potentially wide-ranging impacts on land ecosystems.
properties.description: .uppercase { text-transform:uppercase; } sup, sub { vertical-align: 0; position: relative; } sup { bottom: 0.8ex; } sub { top: 0.8ex; } table {font-family:Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; } Heligoland, Germany Other Impacts Temperature (Air) Temperature (Ocean) Because global warming is changing Europe's ecosystems, migrating songbirds -- and springtime -- are arriving earlier in Heligoland, Germany. This major North Sea flyway is the site of a bird observatory where scientists developed a funnel-shaped trap now used to study migrating birds around the world.1 Key Facts From the flowering of plants to the arrival of migrating birds, spring is coming earlier to Germany.10,16 Shifts in the seasons show that Europe's climate is changing -- with potentially wide-ranging impacts on land ecosystems. Nearly two-fifths of the first spring arrival dates of birds in Europe and North America in the second half the twentieth century occurred significantly earlier than historically, while only 2 percent occurred significantly later.9 Scientists found that warmer temperatures correlated with earlier arrival of small migratory songbirds at Heligoland, Germany, and other sites across northern Europe.10 The effects of global warming in Germany are not limited to birds. Ten spring phases of flowering and leaf unfolding occurred on average 1.6 days earlier each decade in the second half of the twentieth century.16 climatehotmap.org Climate Hot Map is a project of the Union of Concerned Scientists. See detail page for endnotes.
properties.Map Marker Label: Migrating birds arriving earlier in Germany
properties.Hot Spot Image Alt Text: Spring is coming earlier to Germany, including Heligoland,a stop on the North Sea flyway.

properties.name: Warming temperatures threaten Nevada pika habitats
properties.Bullet 1: Studies have found that pikas are vulnerable to climate change, abandoning areas that have warmed the most.3
properties.Bullet 2: Nearly one-third of pika populations studied in the area between the Rocky Mountains and the Sierra Nevada have become locally extinct in recent decades.3,4,5 According to one broad study, abandoned pika sites in the Great Basin tended to be drier and warmer than sites that pikas still occupy.6
properties.Bullet 3: Global warming can take a particularly high toll on mountain species. When their habitat moves to higher elevations, they may have nowhere to go if the mountains where they live are too low.3,7
properties.Hot Spot Image Caption: Global warming is undermining the habitat of the pika, a small relative of the rabbit that lives in rocky alpine areas in Nevada and other parts of the western United States. Several pika populations have become locally extinct in recent decades as their habitat has disappeared.1
properties.Intro: Rising temperatures are threatening the habitat and survival of the pika, a furry mammal that lives in cold areas above 5,000 feet (1,500 meters) in mountains from Colorado to California.3
properties.description: .uppercase { text-transform:uppercase; } sup, sub { vertical-align: 0; position: relative; } sup { bottom: 0.8ex; } sub { top: 0.8ex; } table {font-family:Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; } Duffer Peak, NV, USA Other Impacts Temperature (Air) Freshwater (Land ice) Global warming is undermining the habitat of the pika, a small relative of the rabbit that lives in rocky alpine areas in Nevada and other parts of the western United States. Several pika populations have become locally extinct in recent decades as their habitat has disappeared.1 Key Facts Rising temperatures are threatening the habitat and survival of the pika, a furry mammal that lives in cold areas above 5,000 feet (1,500 meters) in mountains from Colorado to California.3 Studies have found that pikas are vulnerable to climate change, abandoning areas that have warmed the most.3 Nearly one-third of pika populations studied in the area between the Rocky Mountains and the Sierra Nevada have become locally extinct in recent decades.3,4,5 According to one broad study, abandoned pika sites in the Great Basin tended to be drier and warmer than sites that pikas still occupy.6 Global warming can take a particularly high toll on mountain species. When their habitat moves to higher elevations, they may have nowhere to go if the mountains where they live are too low.3,7 climatehotmap.org Climate Hot Map is a project of the Union of Concerned Scientists. See detail page for endnotes.
properties.Map Marker Label: Warming temperatures threaten Nevada pika habitats
properties.Hot Spot Image Alt Text: Pika, relative of the rabbit, in its rocky alpine habitat, Nevada.

properties.name: Higher CO2 levels spur poison ivy growth in North Carolina
properties.Bullet 1: More than 350,000 cases of poison ivy are reported annually in the United States.14
properties.Bullet 2: Approximately 80 percent of people are allergic to urushiol, the oil produced by poison ivy.12
properties.Bullet 3: At the levels of carbon dioxide expected by mid-century, poison ivy grows twice as fast and produces a more toxic urushiol than it does at current carbon dioxide levels.12,16
properties.Hot Spot Image Caption: Poison ivy, which causes an itchy rash in most people, thrives in wooded areas like the Piedmont region of North Carolina. As carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere increase, scientists expect poison ivy to grow faster and become more toxic.1
properties.Intro: The foothills of North Carolina, a region known as the Piedmont, are the academic and industrial heart of the state. Climate change threatens urban, suburban, and rural communities in the Piedmont with increased exposure to allergens—including itchy, painful rashes from poison ivy.
properties.description: .uppercase { text-transform:uppercase; } sup, sub { vertical-align: 0; position: relative; } sup { bottom: 0.8ex; } sub { top: 0.8ex; } table {font-family:Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; } Piedmont, NC, USA Other Impacts People (Health) Temperature (Air) Poison ivy, which causes an itchy rash in most people, thrives in wooded areas like the Piedmont region of North Carolina. As carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere increase, scientists expect poison ivy to grow faster and become more toxic.1 Key Facts The foothills of North Carolina, a region known as the Piedmont, are the academic and industrial heart of the state. Climate change threatens urban, suburban, and rural communities in the Piedmont with increased exposure to allergens—including itchy, painful rashes from poison ivy. More than 350,000 cases of poison ivy are reported annually in the United States.14 Approximately 80 percent of people are allergic to urushiol, the oil produced by poison ivy.12 At the levels of carbon dioxide expected by mid-century, poison ivy grows twice as fast and produces a more toxic urushiol than it does at current carbon dioxide levels.12,16 climatehotmap.org Climate Hot Map is a project of the Union of Concerned Scientists. See detail page for endnotes.
properties.Map Marker Label: Higher CO2 levels spur poison ivy growth in North Carolina
properties.Hot Spot Image Alt Text: Poison ivy and other allergens thrive in CO2-rich air.
